thread.title: Torrey Dale adjusting to move inside at defensive tackle
thread.title_full: Torrey Dale adjusting to move inside at defensive tackle

title: Torrey Dale adjusting to move inside at defensive tackle
text:
Torrey Dale adjusting to move inside at defensive tackle Michael Bonner, The Clarion-Ledger 6:25 p.m. CDT October 21, 2015 Mississippi State junior Torrey Dale moved from the outside to the inside on the defensive line. (Photo: Mississippi State) 12 CONNECT 8 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
STARKVILLE – Two seniors anchored the middle of Mississippi State’s defensive line in 2014. Kaleb Eulls and P.J. Jones started all but one game at defensive tackle last year. Their departures left two spots vacant, specifically inside. 
The hiatus presented an opportunity for junior Torrey Dale. 
The defensive end played in 13 games in his first two seasons. He combined to make six tackles. 
This year at defensive tackle, Dale has made seven tackles in seven games. 
“It’s not been anything I can’t handle. I’ve got coach (David) Turner teaching me everything I need to know about playing inside,” Dale said. “I’d say the biggest adjustment is having a guy outside of you, taking on more double teams. You get used to it, but it’s definitely a major adjustment.” 
Dale played on the outside throughout the spring. The move came during practices in August. Defensive line coach David Turner asked Dale to move inside in the middle of a walkthrough just weeks prior to the season. 
“I guess I did all right,” Dale said. 
The defensive tackle position is often a thankless one. Part of the role is to take on double-teams and allow the defensive ends to feast on single blockers. 
The Kenner, Louisiana native didn’t record a tackle in his first two games this season. He has seven in the last five games. 
“I mean that really helps being in there with guys like A.J. (Jefferson) and Ryan (Brown) who are veterans,” Dale said. “They help lead me in the right direction.” 
Dale is listed in the Mississippi State guide at 252 pounds. He’s up to 273 since the move inside. He’s still the lightest defensive tackle on the roster compared to Chris Jones at 308 pounds or Nick James at 325 pounds. 
“I play stronger inside because I just know that there’s someone from the outside that’s probably going to come block me as well as the guy I’m going against,” Dale said. “Making the move from outside to inside, I’m about 273 so I’m a little D-tackle.” 
But, he’s quicker than most D-tackles too. 
“I’d say I come off quicker than your average D-tackles. You’ve got some freaks like Chris Jones, he’s pretty fast,” Dale said. “I say I give them a challenge with my speed.” 
Contact Michael Bonner at mbonner@jackson.gannett.com. Follow @MikeBBonner on Twitter. 12 CONNECT 8 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://on.thec-l.com/1RX5K7u TOP VIDEOS
